Award.AbstractNarration:
Students who enter college interested in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) disciplines persist, excel, and advance by being exposed to a combination of intellectually challenging classes, rewarding research opportunities, and meaningful mentoring relationships. Unfortunately, many students, and particularly those from groups historically underrepresented in STEM disciplines, do not experience this combination, and are lost from the pool of prospective scientists, with serious consequences for the scientific workforce in the U.S. The Columbia University Bridge Program is designed to give underrepresented post-baccalaureates who may have missed on one or all of these elements the opportunity to make themselves more competitive Ph.D.-program applicants. The Program's emphasis on research experience advances scientific discovery; its flexible coursework, professional development, and mentoring enhance participants' skills while creating a structured, rigorous, and supportive environment in which they can prepare themselves for a successful transition into a graduate program.

This program will fund participants in the Bridge Program, thereby contributing directly to a wide range of research projects across the physical sciences and increasing the participation of underrepresented groups in STEM. Bridge participants are hired as full-time research assistants for up to two years. They conduct research under the mentorship of faculty members, post-doctoral researchers, and graduate students, are provided with funds to support professional expenses, and are eligible for university benefits. The participants enroll in at least one course per semester, and attend monthly one-on-one progress meetings with the Program's Assistant Director. The Program also organizes a number of professional development workshops, provides access to GRE test preparation, and partners with Columbia's School of Continuing Education to ensure success while at Columbia and to facilitate application to Ph.D. programs. In the next few years, a dozen Bridge alumni will earn their Ph.D.s, enabling a start-to-finish evaluation of the impact that the Program has had on its participants' trajectories. The Program's evaluation team will conduct assessments of programmatic elements and develop a data-driven model of best practices that can be shared with the STEM community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Columbia University's Bridge to the Ph.D. in the Natural Sciences Program, now renamed the Bridge to the Ph.D. Program in STEM, is an intensive research, coursework, and mentoring experience for talented post-baccalaureate scholars from groups that have been historically underrepresented in the natural sciences. The Bridge Program’s goal is to increase the number of underrepresented scholars entering Ph.D. programs in the natural sciences and to equip them to succeed in these programs. Bridge participants are hired as full-time Columbia University research assistants for up to two years. They conduct research under the mentorship of faculty members, postdoctoral researchers, and graduate students, are provided with funds to support professional expenses, and are eligible for university benefits. The participants enroll in at least one course per semester, and attend monthly one-on-one progress meetings with the Bridge’s Director. The Program also organizes a number of professional development workshops, provides access to GRE test preparation, and identifies resources on campus to ensure success while at Columbia and to facilitate application to Ph.D. programs.

This project was to help the Bridge Program transition into its next phase. Over the duration of the grant, our ambition was to double the Program’s size, allowing us to create parallel, complementary tracks in the life and physical sciences. This would allow us to tailor the mentoring and professional development aspects of the Program to the differing needs of life- and physical-science participants, while preserving many of the key aspects of our cohort-based model, including—crucially—the individual attention each participant receives.

Over its lifetime, this grant supported research activities for five underrepresented minority Bridge participants who are now engaged in Ph.D. work, and to one participant who is applying to graduate school in the fall of 2019. Amanda Buch is now a Ph.D. student in neuroscience at the Weill Cornell Graduate School of Medical Sciences; Jorge Cortés is in his second year in the astronomy Ph.D. program at Columbia (and also a LSST Corporation Data Science Fellow); Kursti DeLello is a NSF Graduate Research Fellow in the Department of Applied and Engineering Physics at Cornell University; Blanche Fields is a Ph.D. student in the Department of Biological Science at Columbia; and Huda Qureshi is in the applied mathematics program at Columbia. And Rayna Rampalli is planning to transition into a Ph.D. program in astronomy next fall.

In addition to supporting these individuals on their way to a Ph.D., this grant's support of the Bridge Program was critical in enabling its institutionalization. Over the lifetime of the grant, the following took place:

  • a new full-time director for the Program, Dr. Kwame Osei-Sarfo, was hired;
  • the Program settled into Columbia's Fu Foundation School of Engineering and Applied Science, which committed to supporting four participants a year in its disciplines;
  • the Program expanded into the Department of Economics, which committed to supporting two participants a year.

The overall result is that the Program is larger and healthier than it has been in years. In 2015, our entering cohort had only three participants. In 2019, we had eight new participants, in disciplines ranging from chemistry to environmental engineering and from economics to applied physics. And in 2020-21, we should reach our new steady state, with 11 slots divided between the natural sciences (five participants), engineering (four), and economics (two). On-going discussions with the Business School about an expansion there means that the Program might even grow by two more slots in 2021-22.

The Bridge Program is now part of the university landscape in a way that seemed unlikely even three years ago. It is also clearly part of a national landscape that has been more and more willing to incorporate bridge programs into its thinking about how to enhance underrepresented minority participation in STEM. Examples of this include the recent launch of the American Chemical Society's Bridge Program, modeled on the American Physical Society's program (which itself was modeled in part on Columbia's), and the growing recognition that graduate programs should move toward holistic admissions, a feature of bridge program admissions since their inception.
